text: you keep open the drugstore to make sure you can get your prescription? How do you deal with the things that necessarily have to be kept going? And what's the way to do that? There should be a national standard for that. It should be coming out of the Situation Room right now. And by the way, the single most significant thing we can do to deal with the larger problem down the road of income inequality is get rid of Donald Trump. Donald Trump, he's exacerbated every single one of these problems, both the immediate urgent need and how we're going to hold people harmless for the damage done as a consequence of this virus. It's important we do both.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Washington, DC
speaker: Jake Tapper
text: Vice President Biden, Senator Sanders, we want to thank you both for being here tonight under these challenging and trying circumstances. We wish both of you the best.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Tonight, the battle for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, where everything is on the line.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Seven candidates face off in the final debate before the South Carolina and Super Tuesday primaries. I'm Gayle King.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: And I'm Norah O'Donnell. Let's get started.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: The time has come to turn the page and open up a new chapter in the American story.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Let us go forward. Let's win this thing. Let's transform America!

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: America deserves a president who is as resilient as her people.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: 2020 is our time to change who makes the rules.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: This election is just too important, and we cannot afford to get it wrong.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: There's no limit to what we could get done in the next four years.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: Show up in November of 2020 and win.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: Together, we have built a movement.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: We have a fantastically diverse and wonderful party.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: We choose hope over fear.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: We are going to unite together.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: And, together, we are going to get it done.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: We will deliver a democracy worthy of the name.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: We are here, and we are strong. Here are the seven candidates for the presidential nomination.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Good evening, and welcome. The Democratic presidential primary here in South Carolina, the first primary in the South, is just four days away.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: And Super Tuesday is just a week away. And this is the biggest primary day of the year, as voters in 14 states cast ballots, and many of them tell us they have not actually made up their mind. So, this debate, when you think about it tonight, may be the last, best chance for the candidates to make their case to South Carolina and Super Tuesday voters.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: And CBS News is proud too bring you this debate, along with our co-sponsors. They are the Democratic National Committee and the Congressional Black Caucus Institute, a nonpartisan organization committed to educating voters and training political leaders.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: And we are partnering tonight also with Twitter. So, you at home can participate in this debate. How do you do that? Send us your questions for the candidates using the Twitter hashtag #DemDebate.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Now, here are the rules for the next two hours. When you are asked a question, you will have one minute and 15 seconds to answer, and 45 seconds for follow-ups. So, let's begin. Senator Sanders, we haven't had a national unemployment rate this low for this long in 50 years. Here in South Carolina, the unemployment rate is even lower. How will you convince voters that a Democratic socialist can do better than President Trump with the economy?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Well, you're right. The economy is doing really great for people like Mr. Bloomberg and other billionaires. In the last three years, last three years, billionaires in this country saw an $850 billion increase in their wealth. But you know what? For the ordinary American, things are not so good. Last year, real wage increases for the average worker were less than 1 percent. Half of our people are living paycheck to paycheck; 87 million Americans have no health insurance or are underinsured; 45 million people are struggling with student debt; 500,000 people tonight are sleeping out on the street, including 30,000 veterans. That is not an economy that's working for the American people. That's an economy working for the 1 percent. We're going to create an economy for all, not just wealthy campaign contributors.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: Senator...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Mayor Bloomberg...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: Senator...Senator...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Mayor Bloomberg, I'll let you respond to that. Do you think Senator Sanders' economy would be better for America than President Trump's?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: I -- I think that Donald Trump thinks it would be better if he's president. I do not think so. Vladimir Putin thinks that Donald Trump should be president of the United States. And that's why Russia is helping you get elected, so you will lose to him.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Oh, Mr. Bloomberg. Let me tell Mr. Putin, OK, I'm not a good friend of President Xi of China. I think President Xi is an authoritarian leader. And let me tell Mr. Putin, who interfered in the 2016 election, try to bring Americans against Americans, hey, Mr. Putin, if I'm president of the United States, trust me, you're not going to interfere in any more American elections.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator Warren?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: Look, we know what the president -- what Russia wants. It's chaos.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: So, look, the way I see this is that Bernie is winning right now because the Democratic Party is a progressive party, and progressive ideas are popular ideas, even if there are a lot of people on this stage who don't want to say so. You know, but Bernie and I agree on a lot of things, but I think I would make a better president than Bernie. And the reason for that is that getting a progressive agenda enacted is going to be really hard, and it's going to take someone who digs into the details to make it happen. Bernie and I both wanted to help rein in Wall Street. In 2008, we both got our chance. But I dug in. I fought the big banks. I built the coalitions, and I won. Bernie and I both want to see universal health care, but Bernie's plan doesn't explain how to get there, doesn't show how we're going to get enough allies into it, and doesn't show enough about how we're going to pay for it.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Thank...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: I dug in. I did the work. And then Bernie's team trashed me for it. We need a president who is going to dig in, do the hard work, and actually get it done. Progressives have got one shot. And we need to spend it with a leader who will get something done.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Mayor Buttigieg, we want to bring you in this conversation.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Why would the Russians want to be working on behalf of Bernie Sanders?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: I will tell you what the Russians want. They don't have a political party. They want chaos. And chaos is what is coming our way. I mean, look, if you think the last four years has been chaotic, divisive, toxic, exhausting, imagine spending the better part of 2020 with Bernie Sanders vs. Donald Trump. Think about what that will be like for this country. And, meanwhile, folks at home, from South Carolina to South Bend, are trying to figure out what any of this means for us, because it's right that there is a progressive majority, an American majority that wants to see real change, wants to see wages go up, and go up faster than the cost of health and saving for retirement. But, also, there's a majority of the American people who I think right now just want to be able to turn on the TV, see their president, and actually feel their blood pressure go down a little bit, instead of up through the roof.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: We have an opportunity to set a different tone.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Mr. Steyer.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Mr. Steyer.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: Bernie Sanders' analysis is right. The difference is, I don't like his solutions. I don't believe that a government takeover of large parts of the economy makes any sense for working people or for families. I think that what we need to do is to present an alternative that includes a vibrant, competitive private sector. But we all know, unchecked capitalism has failed. The answer is not for the government to take over the private sector, though. The answer is for us to break the corporate stranglehold on our government and have the government work for the people again.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Vice President Biden?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: We need to -- well, let me just finish, because we need to have an alternative to Donald Trump. I'm talking about doubling the minimum wage, cutting taxes by 10 percent for everybody who makes less than $250,000 and creating over 4.5 million good-paying union jobs. Donald Trump thinks -- he's incompetent as a steward of the American economy. We have to show that we can create a growing, prosperous economy that works for American working people.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Thank you, Mr. Steyer. Gayle?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Mr. Steyer, thank you. Your time is up.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: You know, when we talk about progressive, let's talk about being progressive. Walking distance of here is Mother Emanuel Church, nine people shot dead by a white supremacist. Bernie voted five times against the Brady Bill and wanted a waiting period... No, let me finish. A waiting period of 12 hours. I'm not saying he's responsible for the nine deaths, but that man would not have been able to get that weapon with the waiting period had been what I suggest until you are cleared. In addition to that, being progressive, he thought Barack Obama -- he wanted a primary-- he said we should primary Barack Obama, someone should, and, in fact, the president was weak and our administration was in fact not up to it. Look, folks, this is -- let's talk about progressive. Progressive is getting things done, and that's what we got done. We got a lot done

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Senator Sanders -- Senator Sanders, your response.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: You know, Pete mentioned -- I'm hearing my name mentioned a little bit tonight. I wonder why. And maybe, you know, Pete mentions what the American people want. I will tell you, Pete, what the American people want, and, Joe, what the American people want. They don't want candidates to be running to billionaires for huge amounts of funding.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: All right, let's clear this up once and for all.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Pete has gotten funding from over 50 billionaires.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: You've got people believing something that is false. This needs to be cleared up.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Joe, I think, has gotten a little bit more. What the American people want, by the way, and a lot of the issues we'll be discussing tonight are issues I raised four years ago: raising the minimum wage to a living wage, 15 bucks an hour. Making public colleges and universities tuition-free. And finally, doing what every other major country on Earth does, guaranteeing health care to all people as a human right through a Medicare for All, single-payer system.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: I can't allow -- I can't allow this to stand because it's just not true. Senator Sanders...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: We're going to allow everyone an opportunity opportunity to respond.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: ... has got people believing something that is untrue about my campaign. The idea that most of my campaign is funded by billionaires...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: I didn't say that, Pete.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: Fifty people, all right. In Charleston alone, just in Charleston, over 2,000 people have contributed to my campaign. That means the dollars that have come to my campaign, just from Charleston, is more than the dollars that have come from the 50 people that you mentioned. Grassroots contributions are the life blood of my campaign. In fact, I shouldn't miss the opportunity, if you're watching right now and you support my campaign, go to peteforamerica.com, and chip in. And if you are watching right now, and you're a billionaire, I will raise your taxes. But if you'd like to defeat Donald Trump, please go to peteforamerica.com and donate legal maximum of $2,800, if you're a billionaire.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: All right, all right, Mayor Buttigieg. Vice President Biden, I want to make -- I want to bring us to another topic. We're in South Carolina. It's the first primary with a significant black voting population. Your numbers appear to be slipping with black voters. And I'm wondering if you could respond about why that is happening to you at this particular time.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Well, first of all, the latest poll I saw, my numbers -- I'm still 15 points ahead, the latest poll.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Yes, yes, you're correct. You're correct.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: But look, look...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: But Senator Sanders is in striking distance of you. You are within the margin of error in this state.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Well, it depends which -- look, I've earned the vote, I've worked like the devil to earn the vote of the African-American community, not just here but across the country. I've been coming here for years and years, creating jobs here, making sure that the port, for example, that employs one in 11 people, we put $500 million, in our administration, just into this county. We've created jobs for people. The people know me. My entire career has been wrapped up in dealing with civil rights and civil liberties. I don't expect anything. I plan to earn the vote. I'm here to ask. I'm here to earn it. But, folks, I intend to win in South Carolina, and I will win the African-American vote here in South Carolina.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Mr. Biden, will you continue if you do not win South Carolina? You have said that South Carolina will determine the outcome of this presidential race. If you don't win South Carolina, will you continue in this race?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: I will win South Carolina.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: All right, sir. Mayor Bloomberg, I'd like to bring you into this conversation. I want to ask you about a question that impacts the black and brown community. You've apologized for stop and frisk repeatedly. What exactly are you apologizing for?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: We let it get out of control and when I realized that, I cut it back by 95 percent. And I've apologized and asked for forgiveness. I've met with black leaders to try to get an understanding of how I can better position myself and what I should have done and what I should do next time. But let me tell you, I have been working very hard. We've improved the school system for black and brown students in New York City. We've increased the jobs that are available to them. We've increased the housing that's available to them. We have programs like the...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: But what more can you do about this issue, Mr. Mayor, to put people's fears and skepticism to rest? It continues to follow you.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: No -- well, that's because it's in their interest to promote that. But if you talk to the people in New York City, I have over 100 black elected officials that have endorsed me. A lot of them are in the audience tonight. And I've earned the respect of people in New York City. I was the mayor of the largest, most populous city in the United States for 12 years, and people will tell you it's a lot better city today. It is safer for everybody. The school system is better. The budget is under control. We've done the things that people need in New York City for all ethnicities.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Mayor Buttigieg, mayor to mayor, mayor to mayor, you've certainly had your issues with the black community as well. Do you think the New York City's implementation of stop and frisk was racist?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: Yes, in effect, it was. Because it was about profiling people based on their race. And the mayor even said that they disproportionately stopped white people too often and minorities too little. And I'm not here to score points. I come at this with a great deal of humility, because we have had a lot of issues, especially when it comes to racial justice and policing in my own community. And I come to this with some humility because I'm conscious of the fact that there are seven white people on this stage talking about racial justice. None of us -- none of us have the experience, the lived experience of, for example, walking down the street, or in a mall, and feeling feeling eyes on us, regarding us as dangerous, without knowing the first thing about us just because the color of our skin. None of us had the experience that black women have had that drives that maternal mortality gap that we are all rightly horrified by, of going into a doctor, and being less likely to have your description of being in pain believed because of your race. Since we don't have the experience, the next best thing we can do...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Thank you, Mayor.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: ... is actually listen to those who do.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: I know -- wait a second. I know that if I were black, my success would have been a lot harder to achieve. And I know a lot of black people that if they were white it would have been a lot easier for them. That's just a fact, and we've got to do something about it than rather just demagogue about it.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator Klobuchar, was the way that the mayor implemented stop and frisk racist?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: Yes, and I think that what we need to do instead of just reviewing everything from the past is talk about where we're going to go forward. Martin Luther King once said that we are all tied in a single garment of destiny, and that what affects one of us directly affects all of us indirectly. So when there is racism in the criminal justice system, then we need to fix it. And to me that means sentencing reform, like the First Step Act, and extending that to the states with the Second Step Act. It means equal opportunity. Because if we don't pass Representative Clyburn's bill out of South Carolina here to invest in impoverished communities, we're never going to get to that single garment of destiny. And we also need to do something about child care, about making sure we increase the minimum wage. And then, finally, voting. While we are all sitting here debating, Wisconsin has kicked hundreds of thousands of people off of their voting rolls. Georgia kicked 100,000 off. As president, I will get voting rights to be a reality for everyone.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Senator Warren, I'm coming to you. I want to direct this question to you because you -- because Mayor Bloomberg has said he got in this race late because he doesn't believe that any of you on stage can beat Donald Trump. You said Mayor Bloomberg is not the safest candidate, he is the riskiest candidate. What did you mean by that?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: I mean that Mayor Bloomberg -- let's think of it this way. We're here in Charleston, and you know who is going to be in Charleston later this week is Donald Trump. He's going to be here to raise money for his buddy Senator Lindsey Graham, who funded Lindsey Graham's campaign for re-election last time? It was Mayor Bloomberg. And that's not the only right-wing senator that Mayor Bloomberg has funded. In 2016, he dumped $12 million into the Pennsylvania Senate race to help re-elect an anti-choice, right-wing Republican senator. And I just want to say, the woman challenger was terrific. She lost by a single point. In 2012, he scooped in to try to defend another Republican senator against a woman challenger. That was me. It didn't work, but he tried hard. I don't care how much money Mayor Bloomberg has. The core of the Democratic Party will never trust him. He has not earned their trust. I will. And the fact that he cannot earn the trust of core of the Democratic Party means he is the riskiest candidate standing on this stage.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: All right, Senator Warren, thank you. Mayor Bloomberg, would you like to respond? Mayor Bloomberg?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: I have been training for this job since I stepped on the pile that was still smoldering on 9/11. I know what to do. I've shown I know how to run a country. I've run the city which is almost the same size -- bigger than most countries in the world. I am not the -- I'm the one choice that makes some sense. I have the experience. I have the resources. And I have the record. And all those sideshows that the senator wants to bring up have nothing to do with that. When people hired me to run New York City three times, in an overwhelmingly Democratic, progressive city, they elected me again and again.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Mr. Vice President?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: I was mentioned in this.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: No...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: I'd like to respond.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Go ahead, Senator.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: He called me out by name.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: There was a -- I thought...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: ... and referred to what I talk about as a "sideshow." You know, this is personal for me. When I was 21 years old, I got my first job as a special education teacher. I loved that job. And by the end of the first year, I was visibly pregnant. The principal wished me luck and gave my job to someone else. Pregnancy discrimination, you bet. But I was 21 years old. I didn't have a union to protect me. And I didn't have any federal law on my side. So I packed up my stuff, and I went home. At least I didn't have a boss who said to me, "Kill it," the way that Mayor Bloomberg is alleged to have said...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: I never said that. Oh, come on.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: ... to one of his pregnant employees. People want a chance to hear......People want a chance to hear from the women who have worked for...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: I never said that. And for the record, if she was a teacher in New York City, she would never have had that problem. We treated our teachers the right way, and the unions will tell you exactly that.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Well, Mayor Bloomberg, Senator Warren has raised...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: Then let us -- let us have -- the women have an opportunity to speak. The Bloomberg corporations and Mayor Bloomberg himself have been accused of discrimination. They are bound by nondisclosures so that they cannot speak. If he says there is nothing to hide here, then sign a blanket release and let those women speak out...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: ... so that they can tell their stories the way I can tell my story without having the fear they're going to be sued by a billionaire.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Thank you. Thank you. We have a number of issues to discuss tonight, but I want to give the mayor an opportunity to respond, because she has raised concerns about women in your workplace. At the last debate, you said some of your female employees might not have liked some of your jokes. Did these women take your jokes wrong? Or were you wrong to make the jokes?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: Probably wrong to make the jokes. I don't remember what they were. So I assume -- if it bothered them, I was wrong, and I apologize. I'm sorry for that. But what happened here is we went back 40 years and we could only find three cases where women said they were uncomfortable. Nobody accused me of doing anything other than just making a comment or two. And what the senator did suggest was that we release these women from the nondisclosure agreement. I did that two days later, and my company has said we will not use nondisclosure agreements ever again. The senator has got it. And I don't know what else she wants us to do.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: Oh, I'll be clear.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: We're following exactly what she asked to do.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: I'll tell you exactly what I want you to do.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: And the trouble is with this senator, enough is never enough for what this -- I'm going to start focusing on some of these other things. We just cannot continue to re-litigate this every time. We did what she asked. And, thank you, we've probably made the world better because of it. And by my company renouncing using these, we probably changed, hopefully, the corporate landscape all across America.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: If you get nominated, we'll be re-litigating this all year.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: Sorry, Mayor, you did not do what I asked.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Senator Warren, that is a very serious charge that you leveled at the mayor.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: Yes.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: He told a woman to get an abortion. What evidence do you have of that?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: Her own words.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: And, Mayor Bloomberg, could you respond to this?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: I never said it, period, end of story. Categorically never said it. When it was accused -- when I was accused of doing it, we couldn't figure out what she was talking about. But right now, I'm sorry if she heard what she thought she heard, or whatever happened. I didn't take any pleasure in that. And we've just got to go on. But I never said it. Come on.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: What I asked the mayor to do is to do a release of all people who have discrimination claims...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: We are doing that, Senator.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: We want to get to the -- we want to get to the issue -- we want to get to the issue of electability and the ideological difference within the Democratic Party.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: OK.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator Sanders, the cost of your agenda. Yesterday, you released information about how you will pay for your major proposals, but not all of your details are clear. You've proposed more than $50 trillion in new spending.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Over a 10-year period.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: You've said Medicare for all will cost $30 trillion.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: But you can only explain how you'll pay for just about half of that. Can you do the math for the rest of us?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: How many hours do you have?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Two.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: That's the problem.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: No, it's not the problem. All right, let's talk about Medicare for all. I'm sure you're familiar with the new study that just came out of Yale University, published in Lancet magazine, one of the prestigious medical journals in the world. You know what it said? Medicare for all will lower health care costs in this country by $450 billion a year and save 68,000 lives of people who otherwise would have died.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: What we need to do is to do what every other major country on Earth does
text: guarantee health care to all people, not have thousands of separate insurance plans, which are costing us some $500 billion a year to administer. Our plan -- we have laid out options all over the place. One of the options is a 7.5 percent payroll tax on employers, which will save them substantial sums of money. Another...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: Bernie, let me -- let me respond to this.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: You asked me a question.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator Klobuchar, does the math add up?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: No, the math does not add up. In fact, just on "60 Minutes" this weekend, he said he wasn't going to rattle through the nickels and the dimes. Well, let me tell you how many nickels and dimes we're talking about: nearly $60 trillion. Do you know how much that is, for all of his programs?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Not true.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: That is three times the American economy -- not the federal government -- the entire American economy. The Medicare for all plan alone on page eight clearly says that it will kick 149 million Americans off their current health insurance in four years. That is true. As one prominent Democrat once said, we should pay attention to where the voters of this country are, Bernie. That prominent Democrat was Barack Obama a few months ago. And I think that's what we should do. They are not with you on spending nearly $60 trillion.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: First of all...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: What I think we should do is make things more affordable, nonprofit public option, make sure we're paying for long-term care better, take on the pharmaceuticals, like you and I have done together...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Thank you, Senator.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: ... and do something for the people of America.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Thank you, Senator Klobuchar.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: Instead of a bunch of broken promises that sound good on bumper stickers.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Mr. Steyer -- Mr. Steyer...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: I think we're talking about math.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: We'll get to you, Mr. Sanders.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: Let's talk about it.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: Can I say something?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: No, let me go.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: No, I think -- Tom, I think she was talking about my plan, not yours.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: I think we were talking about math, and it doesn't take two hours to do the math.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: No, no, well, let's talk about math.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: Because let's talk about what it adds up to.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Let's talk about math.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: Let's talk about math, indeed. OK, so here's the math...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: If we do nothing is what...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: No, here's the math.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Excuse me, can I respond to the attack?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: To do nothing is what will happen...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator Sanders, you are allowed a quick response and then we would like to allow the other candidates...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Listen to the moderator, guys.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator Sanders. Senator Sanders.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: The moderator -- is it my turn?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: This helps a lot, doesn't?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator Sanders, you have been name checked. You are allowed to respond.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: OK. What the Health and Human Services have said in analyzing health care costs, what Yale -- recent Yale study has said is that your program would cost some $50 trillion over a 10-year period. We would continue to pay in some cases 10 times more for the same exact prescription drugs. What every study out there -- conservative or progressive -- says, Medicare for all will save money. Ours will cost about $45 billion, not $60 trillion.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: Bernie, I was talking about -- I was talking about...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: We would like -- Senator Sanders, we would like to bring Mr. Steyer in on this conversation.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: Mr. Steyer, please.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: I was talking about all your programs.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: Excuse me, Amy. This conversation shows a huge risk for the Democratic Party. We are looking at a party that has decided that we're either going to support someone who is a democratic socialist or somebody who has a long history of being a Republican. And let me say that I got into this race because I wanted to fight for economic justice, for racial justice, and to make sure we had climate justice for the American people. And I am scared. If we cannot pull this party together, if we go to one of those extremes, we take a terrible risk of re-electing Donald Trump.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Thank you, Mr. Steyer.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: And that is something -- I still have some time. And let me say this.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: That is a risk that will hurt the American people in a way that none of us on this stage should be willing to risk.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Thank you. Let's keep this topic going. Mayor Pete?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: So let's do this math. Senator Sanders at one point said it was going to be $40 trillion, then it was $30 trillion, then it was $17 trillion. That's an incredible shrinking price tag. At some point, has said it is unknowable to even see what the price tag would be. Now there are new numbers. I'll tell you exactly what it adds up to. It adds to four more years of Donald Trump, Kevin McCarthy as speaker of the House, and the inability to get the Senate into Democratic hands. The time has come for us to stop acting like the presidency is the only office that matters. Not only is this a way to get Donald Trump reelected.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: We got a House to worry about. We got a Senate to worry about. And this is -- this is really important. Look...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Hello?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: ... if you want to keep the House in Democratic hands, you might want to check with the people who actually turned the House blue, 40 Democrats, who are not running on your platform.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: They are running away from your platform as fast as they possibly can. I want to send those Democrats back to the United States House.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Vice President Biden.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: Let's listen to them...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: ... when they say that they don't want to be out there defending Senator Sanders...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Thank you, Mayor Buttigieg. Thank you, Mayor Buttigieg. Vice President Biden, please.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Whoa. Whoa. Whoa. I guess the only way you do this is jump in and speak twice as long as you should. Here's the deal. Here's the deal. Look, a guy who's a friend of mine down here named Fritz Hollings -- he passed away -- he said, you want to know what a woman will do, look what they have done. Look what they have done. You talk about -- concerned about race. Well, my good friend on the end of this platform, he, in fact, bought a system that was a private prison system, after, after he knew that, in fact, what happened was, they hog-tied young men in prison here in this state. They, in fact, made sure that, in Georgia, they did not have health care for the people who were being held. They, in fact, went on, and he said, after he knew that, he bought it. And then he said he was proud of his accomplishment. You talk about what we're talking about with Bernie. Bernie, in fact, hasn't passed much of anything. The fact of the matter is...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: OK. But I get to answer.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: No, no, no.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: I get to answer that.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: The -- look -- look...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: No, that...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: ... fact is...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: You're out of time. I get to answer...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Here's the deal. I'm not out of time. You spoke over time, and I'm going to talk. Here's the deal.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Here's the deal. The fact of the matter is, look at what's happening here. Look at what's happening here. We have to win the Senate back. And, by the way, I went into all of those races that got 41 new Democrats. The majority of them are supporting me for president and endorsing me.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: And, Mr. Vice President, I have to allow -- yes, Mr. Mayor.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Mr. Mayor, you're allowed to respond.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: I bought stock in a prison company thinking they would do a better job. And I investigated. And I sold it.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: OK.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: But you knew -- you knew when you bought it they'd done that.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: I get to answer this question. And, in fact, since then, I have worked to end the use of private prisons in my home state, and we have ended it. I have started a bank to support black ownership of businesses, women ownership of businesses, and Latino owners of businesses, because this financial service industry is prejudiced. I have worked tirelessly on this. And you know I'm right. You wrote the crime bill that you called...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Where we come from, that's called Tommy come lately.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: There are other people here.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: ... crime bill that put hundreds of thousands of young black and Latino men in prison.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Not true.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: OK. Let me say something.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: There's something going on here. I have worked for racial justice...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Thank you.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Thank you, Mr. Steyer.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: ... completely. And that is an absolute unfair statement.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: All I know...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Tommy come lately.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Mayor Bloomberg. Mayor Bloomberg.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: ... if we spend the next four months tearing our party apart, we're going to watch Donald Trump spend the next four years tearing our country apart.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Look...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: So, my argument here is that we need to get back to what's happening right now. We have a clear choice of who's going to lead this party. And I am the only one in the New Hampshire debate, when asked, if we had a problem with a socialist leading the ticket, that raised my hand. I like Bernie. We came in together to the Senate. But I do not think that this is the best person to lead the ticket.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: And if you want to talk about getting things done and make a comparison, according to Vanderbilt University in Tennessee, last Congress, I was the most effective Democrat in the U.S. Senate on 15 metrics. Bernie and Elizabeth were in the bottom half. It matters -- it matters if you can actually get things done.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: OK. Gayle...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: It is not just who talks the best, who actually gets things done. And especially with the African-American community, there have been a lot of broken promises.. And I think having someone that keeps their promises and follows through and is going to get things done for these people matters. And that's why I ask for your support.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Mayor Bloomberg, please.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: Let's just go on the record. They talk about 40 Democrats; 21 of those were people that I spent $100 million to help elect. All of the new Democrats that came in and put Nancy Pelosi in charge and gave the Congress the ability to control this president......I -- I got them. Number two, when you talk about money, let's put this in perspective. The federal budget is $4.5 trillion a year. We get $3.5 trillion in revenue. We lose $1 trillion a year. That's why the federal budget -- deficit is -- right now, the debt is $20 trillion, going up to 21. We just cannot afford some of this stuff people talk about. But if you...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: Let me finish. If you keep on going, we will elect Bernie. Bernie will lose to Donald Trump. And Donald Trump and the House and the Senate and some of the statehouses will all go red. And then, between gerrymandering and appointing judges, for the next 20 or 30 years, we're going to live with this catastrophe.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Mayor Bloomberg, thank you. I will allow Senator Sanders a quick response, and then Senator Warren.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Thank you very much, Norah.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator Sanders, a quick response, and then Senator Warren.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Thank you very much. Mayor Bloomberg has a solid and strong and enthusiastic base of support. The problem is, they're all billionaires. Now, if you look -- oh. On the other hand, of the last 50 polls that have been done nationally, Mr. Bloomberg, I beat Trump 47 of those 50 times. If you look at battleground states like Michigan, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania, polling just done this Sunday...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: The polls aren't the election.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: ... I beat Trump. And if you want to beat Trump, what you're going to need is an unprecedented...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: ... grassroots movement of black and white and Latino, Native American and Asian, people who are standing up and fighting for justice.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: That's what our movement is about.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: Can anybody -- can anybody in this room imagine moderate Republicans going over and voting for him?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Absolutely.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: And you have to do that, or you can't win.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: You know, that is...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Thank you. Senator Warren.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: That is the problem. And that is that a progressive agenda is popular, Mayor Bloomberg. And, for everyone on this stage, we talk about how to build a future. That's what matters. I talk to people in selfie lines every day who tell me about the importance of getting real help on health care. It's why I also have a way to pay for health care that doesn't raise taxes on middle-class families. But it's so much more than that. As Democrats, we need to speak to the future we can build together. We need to speak of the prosperity we can build together. How about a wealth tax in America? Because with a 2 cent tax on just the top one-tenth of 1 percent, we have a chance to invest in universal child care for every one of our babies, to really level the playing field.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: Put $50 billion into historically black colleges and universities.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: And start closing the racial wealth gap by canceling student loan debt for 43 million Americans.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: We need to talk about our aspirations, our hopes. This is a moment...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: ... to choose hope over fear.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator, thank you.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: This is our moment.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator, thank you. We have to take a quick break. When we come back, the Democratic presidential debate continues right after this, only on CBS.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: I'm Gayle King with Norah O'Donnell. Joining us now on the question here in Charleston, South Carolina are CBS News colleagues, the A team, Bill Whitaker of "60 MINUTES," chief Washington correspondent, that's Major Garrett, and Margaret Brennan, moderator of "FACE THE NATION." We're going to begin with you, Vice President Biden, for this part. Just across the street, as you mentioned at the top of the debate, is the theater where nine people were shot and killed inside the Mother Emanuel Church. We all remember that day back in 2015. And every day in our country, over 100 people die from gun violence. You all have plans, I know, on this stage, to address the gun crisis. But Congress has not been able to pass a major gun legislation in a quarter of a century. And just think about this, in those 25 years we've had Columbine, Newtown, Parkland, Las Vegas. We could go on and on. Vice President Biden, I want to start with you, why should anyone have faith that you're the one who can get this done now?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Because I'm the only one that ever got it done nationally. I beat the NRA twice. I got assault weapons banned. I got magazines that could not hold more than 10 rounds in them. I got them eliminated. Except we had a thing called an election with hanging chads in Florida and it was not reauthorized. In addition to, that I passed the Brady Bill with waiting periods. I led that fight. But my friend to my right and others have in fact also gave into the gone manufacturers, absolute immunity. Imagine if I stood here and said we'd give immunity to drug companies. We would give immunity to tobacco companies. That has caused carnage on our streets, 150 million people have been killed since 2007 when Bernie voted to exempt the gun manufacturers from liability. More than all the wars, including Vietnam, from that point on. Carnage on our streets. And I want to tell you, if I'm elected, NRA, I'm coming for you, and gun manufacturers, I'm going to take you on and I'm going to beat you. I'm the only one who has done it.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: That's why we have got to change what Washington can deliver.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: So this is about being able to dig in and talk about what really it's going to take to get something done. I've been in the Senate. What I've seen is gun safety legislation introduced, get a majority, and then doesn't pass because of the filibuster. Understand this, the filibuster is giving a veto to the gun industry. It gives a veto to the oil industry. It's going to give a veto on immigration. Until we're willing to dig in and say that if Mitch McConnell is going to do to the next Democratic president what he did to President Obama, and that is try to block every single thing he does, that we are willing to roll back the filibuster, go with the majority vote, and do what needs to be done for the American people.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: We're going to stay on this top and allow Senator...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: ... and I can beat Mitch McConnell.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: Understand this, many people on this stage do not support rolling back the filibuster. Until we're ready to do that, we can't have real change.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: I want to allow Senator Sanders to respond because you've gone after the insurance industry. You've taken on pharmaceutical companies. And you've taken on big tech. Why did you vote repeatedly to give gun manufacturers a pass?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Well, you know, Joe has voted for terrible trade agreements. No, no, no, no, no. Joe voted for the war in Iraq. My point was, not to be -- I have cast thousands of votes, including bad votes. That was a bad vote. I have today a D-minus voting record from the NRA. Thirty years ago, I likely lost a race for the one seat for Congress in Vermont because 30 years ago, I opposed -- I supported a ban on assault weapons. Thirty years ago. Right now, my view is we need to expand background checks, end the gun show loophole, and do what the American people want, not what the NRA wants.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: OK, but wait a second...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: ... the opposition to the filibuster is not a discretion from a long time ago.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: I think she recognized me, thank you. I have a 6 million-person organization around this country. Moms Demand Action and Everytown. We have put background checks -- we have got background checks in 20 states. So you can do it. It's Congress that can't seem to do it. And I don't know why we think they're going to do it. The vice president voted for a death bill, and supported the NRA. And certainly Senator Sanders has supported the NRA. But we can do this. We have just got to stop talking about it.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: But the way we do it -- the way we do it is having someone leading the ticket from a part of the country that we actually needs the votes. So I have long supported the assault weapon ban. I am the author of the bill to close the boyfriend loophole that says that domestic abusers can't go out and get an AK-47.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: I wrote that law.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: That bill, along with -- you didn't write that bill. I wrote that bill.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: I wrote the bill, the Violence Against Women Act...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: OK. You did you that.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: ... that took out of the hands of people who abused their...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: OK. We'll have a fact check look at this.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: Let's look at the fact check...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: Oh my goodness.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Joe Biden
text: The only thing that the boyfriend loophole is was not covered. I couldn't get that covered. You, in fact, when you were -- as a senator tried to get it covered and Mitch McConnell is holding it up on his desk right now, and we're going to lose the Violence Against Women Act across the board.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: OK. So, if I could finish. I have the bill. Anyone can check it out, to close the boyfriend loophole. Also to close the Charleston loophole is another bill that is out there. Universal background checks. But let me say how we win this. We have got to win in the middle of the country. And while everyone talks about winning rural areas, suburban areas, I'm the only one up here with a receipts that has actually repeatedly, while being for the assault weapon ban, won in Republican congressional districts over and over again, including Michele Bachmann's district. So having someone that can lead the ticket, that can bring people with her, is the way you get gun safety legislation. I look at these proposals and say, do they hit my uncle Dick in the deer stand? They do not. So coming from a proud hunting state and still being able to pass this legislation is going to be the key.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Norah O'Donnell
text: Senator Klobuchar, thank you. We want to allow many people to get in on this topic. Mayor Buttigieg.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: I'm definitely on board with the part about sending up somebody from the middle of the country. But I want to come back to this question about the filibuster because this is not some long-ago bad vote that Bernie Sanders took, this is a current bad position that Bernie Sanders holds. And we're in South Carolina. How are we going to deliver a revolution if you won't even support a rule change? We are in this state.... We are in the state where Strom Thurmond used the filibuster to block civil rights legislation repeatedly. No less a Senate traditional figure than Harry Reid has called for it to go. It has got to go, because otherwise Washington will not deliver. I was in high school when the Columbine shooting happened. And I remember everybody in Washington saying, never again, we'll never let this happen again. And then a second school shooting generation has now been produced. Shame on us if we allow there to be a third. And also...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: ... in terms of making the case, I think it wouldn't be a bad idea for somebody to illustrate, from the perspective of the a veteran, why the kinds of weaponry, anything remotely like what I trained on in order to go serve in a war zone has no business being sold anywhere near an American school or church or neighbor.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: All right, Senator Sanders, please.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Thirty years ago, I supported a ban on assault weapons. Mike Bloomberg has started a very good organization, Moms Demand Actions. Congratulations.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: Thank you.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: They have credited me with gun sense, as you know.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: Yes, we did.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: Furthermore, furthermore, it is my view, the time is now, and Joe made this point, look, at the end of the day we need to rally the American people. Here is the good news. Because of all these disgusting and horrific mass shootings, the American people now understand that we must be aggressive on gun safety, not be dictated to by the NRA. And I am proud that I have a D-minus voting record from the NRA. If elected president, it will get worse than that.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: All right, Mr. Steyer, please? Mr. Steyer?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: Look, it isn't a question of the American people deciding that we have too much gun violence. Everyone in America knows we have too much gun violence. The problem we have is that corporations have bought Washington, D.C. The gun manufacturers own the Senate of the United States. So even though more than 90 percent of Americans want mandatory background checks on every gun purchase, we can't get it through the Senate. So the question you have to ask yourself is, how do we change the Senate of the United States in a material way? And there are two things. That's why I am for term limits of 12 years for every congressperson and senator, to change who's in charge, to get rid of Mitch McConnell and Lindsey Graham and Ted Cruz. But I am also -- Senator Sanders is right. We need to win a huge victory across the board.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: All right, Mr. Steyer.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: Democrats need to go to the grassroots. I built one of the biggest grassroots organizations in the United States.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Your time's up, sir.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: The way to win at the grassroots is, tell the truth and organize.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Gayle King
text: Your time's up, sir. Bill Whitaker?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Tom Steyer
text: That's what it's going to take in 2020.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bill Whitaker
text: Let's talk about education. South Carolina's schools score in the bottom half of the national assessment. Black students here consistently score worse than white students. Mayor Bloomberg, a key element of your response to failing schools in New York City was a dramatic increase in public charter schools. As president, would you pursue that same strategy and seek to expand charter schools nationwide?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Michael Bloomberg
text: I'm not sure they're appropriate every place. I can only tell you, in New York, they provided parents with an alternative to send students to them. We had -- the charter schools are mixed in with the non-charter public schools, because our charter schools are public schools, as well. They've helped each other. I saw a statistic the other day, when I came into office, zero New York City schools were in the top 25 of the state. When I left, 23 out of 25 were from New York City. We've cut the gap between the rich and the poor. We've made an enormous difference in all of the options that parents have. I raised teacher salaries by 43 percent. I put an extra $5 billion into our school system. I value education. It is the only way to solve the poverty problem is to get people a good education. And rather than just talk about it in New York, we actually did it.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bill Whitaker
text: Senator Warren?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: So this is one thing where a president can make a big difference all by herself. And I'm going to start with my secretary of education. My secretary of education will be someone who has taught in public school. My secretary of education will be someone who believes in public education. And my secretary of education will believe that public dollars should stay in public schools. One more thing. My secretary of education will believe that it is time to get rid of high-stakes testing. We need to support our children. But, look, we want to build a future in this country? We build a future by investing in our children. I've got a plan to put $800 billion new federal dollars into our public schools.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bill Whitaker
text: Thank you. Thank you, Senator.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Elizabeth Warren
text: Education is not free. We must invest in the future of our children.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bill Whitaker
text: Senator Sanders?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: This campaign, our campaign, our campaign is about changing American priorities. Instead of giving tax breaks to billionaires, we're going to have high-quality, universal childcare for every family in this country. Because the psychologists tell us 0 to 4 are the most important years of human development. We are going to triple funding for low-income Title I schools, because kids' education should not depend upon the ZIP Code in which they live. We're going to make public colleges and universities tuition-free through a tax on Wall Street speculation. And we're going to move to make certain that no teacher in America earns less than $60,000 a year.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bill Whitaker
text: Thank you, Senator.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bernie Sanders
text: We want great teachers.

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Amy Klobuchar
text: Can I...

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Bill Whitaker
text: Mayor Buttigieg?

debate_name: 2020 Democratic Candidates Debate in Charleston, South Carolina
speaker: Pete Buttigieg
text: Look, the best thing that we can do to support public education is to support public educators. I'm a little biased, because I'm married to one.
